awd_titl_txt: The Biology and Mathematics Educator Scholarship Project to Prepare Future Secondary Education STEM Teachers
awd_abstract_narration:
With funding from the National Science Foundation's Robert Noyce Teacher Scholarship program, the Biology and Mathematics Educator Scholarship Project to Prepare Future Secondary Education STEM Teachers will recruit undergraduate majors in biology or mathematics and prepare them to become secondary biology or mathematics teachers. The project will fund 18 scholarships over five years. In this project, Sacred Heart University will collaborate with two high-need school districts to offer preparation that will increase the number of undergraduate biology and mathematics majors entering secondary education. Project activities will include new STEM-specific teacher education curricula and supports that will enable STEM teachers to be effective in a high-need, multicultural classroom. These exceptionally qualified biology and mathematics majors will receive scholarships during their junior and senior years as a STEM major and during one post-baccalaureate year while they earn a Master of Arts in Teaching. The project's objectives are to recruit, retain, and graduate the Noyce scholars; to have them fulfill their teaching commitment; to ensure they benefit from current and innovative best practices that prepare them to teach in high-need STEM classrooms; to provide them with inquiry-based research experiences that improve their understanding and ability to teach the nature of science and research; and to prepare them as effective teachers as evidenced by their students' success.

The project will implement enhanced curricular and extracurricular activities to achieve the project goals of increasing both the number and effectiveness of highly qualified biology and mathematics teachers graduating from Sacred Heart University who subsequently teach in high-need secondary school districts. Project activities will develop undergraduate and graduate courses integrating mathematics and science within the framework of STEM education, create research and service-learning opportunities, provide mentoring, and foster the development of a professional teaching identity to increase persistence and avoid the high teacher turnover currently experienced by partnering districts. The institution will develop two new courses to prepare the scholars to break down silos between science and mathematics and to better prepare their secondary students to understand knowledge transfer between settings. This will particularly benefit students in multicultural and high-need classrooms who need multiple perspectives and reinforcement to improve both mathematics and science skills. Additional foci of these courses will be on teaching project-based inquiry learning and grounding instruction in relevant, community-based applications. Participation in STEM research with peer support will improve the scholars' understanding of science and mathematics practices and their ability to communicate and teach inquiry-based activities, and service learning will promote community engagement. A long-term mentoring relationship and additional professional identity development will cement the scholars' self-confidence and help them persist in a challenging position. The project evaluation and research will generate evidence in support of the new curriculum, as well as scholar participation in STEM research, service learning, mentoring, and professional identity development.

por.por_cntn:
The NSF Robert Noyce scholarship program, Biology and Mathematics Educator (BioMe), at Sacred Heart University (SHU) recruited, retained, and prepared 17 high quality biology and mathematics Scholars to teach at the secondary level in high-needs school districts. Beginning in the spring 2016 semester, rising juniors were recruited to begin the program. Once accepted, Noyce scholars received funding for partial tuition costs in their junior and senior years of undergraduate study.  This is followed by partial funding to complete a one-year master of arts in teaching degree for teacher certification. In each semester of their junior and senior years, students took a specialized course called Integrating Mathematics and Biology Across the Curriculum (IMBAC) which was a seminar-style class designed to crosscut mathematics and science into NGSS and CCSS-M frameworks as well as building an awareness of STEM educational issues. Concurrently with IMBAC, the scholars were placed in the classrooms to be apprentices of Master Mentors, who are current and experienced teachers in local school districts. Students observed classes, participated in lesson planning, aided in the classroom, and had the opportunity to teach classes in a highly scaffolded manner. In between their junior and senior years, they engaged in service learning opportunities for high-needs middle and high school students through tutoring, enrichment programming, and community based STEM activities. During their entire experience as Noyce scholars, they were members of professional teacher organizations and had the opportunity to co-present at local, regional, and national conferences.

This grant successfully funded and produced 17 teachers of biology or mathematics that are currently working in high-needs districts. It contributed to the ongoing discussion of SHU?s mission to effectively prepare future middle school and high school STEM teachers. It created stronger partnerships with local school districts and developed effective collaborative working relationships between the Farrington College of Education & Human Development faculty and the College of Arts & Sciences faculty. Scholars in the program have reported that this experience positioned them to successfully obtain competitive teaching positions. The early experiences in classrooms with their Master Mentors, combined with the IMBAC seminar, and other intentionally designed opportunities provided Scholars with valuable experiences and resources which created in-depth knowledge about their respective fields of study and the overall teaching profession.
